newsitem.title: JAPAN: AT&T launches low-cost Internet service in Japan.
newsitem.headline: AT&T launches low-cost Internet service in Japan.

text.p: U.S. telephone giant AT&T Corp launched a low-cost Internet access service on Thursday for individual users in Japan.
AT&T Jens Corp, a joint venture between AT&T and 25 Japanese firms, said the service offers Japanese users unlimited access to the Internet for a flat rate of 2,000 yen ($17) per month.
The one-time registration fee is 3,000 yen ($26).
In addition, users need to pay standard telephone service charges.
The rates are lower than those of other such services in Japan, including Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp's planned Open Computer Network (OCN).
NTT will charge 2,300 yen ($20) per month for access to the Internet for up to 15 hours a month under the OCN service expected to start later this month.
Asked about NTT's service, Darryl Green, president of AT&T Jens, said it was important to work with Japan's Posts and Telecommunications Ministry so that NTT "does not use its dominant position".

AT&T launched an Internet access service for consumers in the United States in March. It has signed up more than 425,000 customers since then and has become the second-biggest provider in the United States, Green said.
AT&T Jens operates a powerful, high-capacity Internet backbone network connected with the United States and Asia-Pacific countries.
It was the first commercial Internet service provider in Japan when it launched a service for users other than scholars and researchers in 1992. Users of the service were mostly businesses.

The giant company's entry into the broader Internet access market in Japan is expected to have a large impact on more than 1,000 secondary service providers which rely on networks of giant carriers such as AT&T.
